head.title: The Quick and the Doomed: Anand Wins in Rapid Play

hedline.hl1: The Quick and the Doomed: Anand Wins in Rapid Play

abstract.p: Robert Byrne chess column discusses Indian grandmaster Viswanathan Anand's victory in Fujitsu Siemens Giants Tournament; diagram (M)

block.p: It's rare that Garry Kasparov fails to win first prize, but it happened in the Fujitsu Siemens Giants Tournament in Frankfurt, June 22 to June 25.

In this elite competition with a quick-play time limit of all moves in 25 minutes, Viswanathan Anand was in his element. The quick-thinking Indian grandmaster took first place with a 7 1/2-2 1/2 score. It was the third time he had won this double-round tournament.
[Diagram]
Anand was at his best in his game with Alexei Shirov, a grandmaster who lives in Spain, in the ninth round. A whirlwind mating attack was his weapon.

The Steinitz Variation of the French Defense, 4 e5, avoids the early exchange of pieces that can arise from 4 Bg5 de 5 Ne4 Be7 6 Bf6 gf (or 6 . . . Bf6). It also sidesteps the challenging MacCutcheon Variation with 4 Bg5 Bb4.
However, after 4 . . . Nfd7, Steinitz used to favor 5 f4 c5 6 Nf3 Nc6 7 Be3, although lately Black has made a living with 7 . . . cd 8 Nd4 Bc5 9 Qd2 Nd4 10 Bd4 Bd4 11 Qd4 Qb6 12 Qb6 Nb6.

That may be one reason why there is a small return to the build-up of a massive pawn center with 5 Nce2 c5 6 c3 Nc6 7 f4. Long considered too slow-paced, it has lately been taken up by Anand and a few followers.

A month ago in Leon, Spain, these two players contested the same opening through 7 Be3, when the play diverged with 7 . . . b5 8 a3 cd 9 Nd4 Nd4 10 cd b4 11 a4 Qa5 12 Bd2 Be7 13 Nf3 O-O 14 Bb5 Nb6 15 b3 Ba6 16 Ba6 Qa6 17 a5 Nd7 18 Qe2 Nb8 19 Kf2 Qe2 20 Ke2. Anand brilliantly converted his space advantage into victory in the endgame.

After 8 . . . Be7, a Lalic-Speelman game in Hastings at the turn of the year gave a positional advantage to White after 9 g3 a5 10 h4 a4 11 Bh3, but Speelman had a deeper grasp of the situation and later won cleverly.
There was no rush for Shirov to castle and give away the location of his king with 9 . . . O-O. He could have kept his powder dry with 9 . . . a5.
Instead of 11 . . . a5, Shirov played 11 . . . Na5; after 12 b4 cb 13 ab Nc4, Shirov had a nice outpost for his queen knight. Anand owned the rest of the board.
Perhaps after 17 . . . Bg5 Shirov had hoped for 18 hg?!, when he could barricade his king position with 18 . . . Nf8. But Anand's 18 Qg5! was another matter altogether.
Anand's killing maneuver was 21 Bc4! dc 22 b5!, which put his queen bishop decisively into the fray after 22 . . . Qb5 23 Ba3!
Anand's 25 Rg6! hg 26 Qg6 Kh8 27 Qf7 Rg8 28 Bf8! settled matters. If 28 . . . Nf8, then 29 Nf6 forces mate. Shirov gave up.
